1000: %oth, you look like that %ra, %pcn. Is that you, %pcf?
You're not by any chance %pcn, are you?
Wait a minute. You're not %pcn, are you?
1002: "Thief! You're the one who stole my _gem_! _guard_! Kill!"   As you hear the accusation, you know it to be false. Mayhap you have filched a gem from time to time, but there is no way this one should be pinned on you.

"You've got a lot of nerve coming back here after taking my _gem_! My associate =guard_ will take care of your business now."   Something is clearly wrong. This person has no reason to be upset with you.
1004: "So, it wasn't you who stole my _gem_ at all. %oth, I feel ashamed for wrongly accusing you. Here, please accept this _reward_ as my apology. I'll make certain that the %cn guards know that you're an innocent %ra."   You know in your heart that even if _qgiver_ speaks on your behalf, your reputation will never be the same.
1005: They always have the best information in _inn_.
_inn_ is the only place I'd go for really choice information.
When they find that %ra thief, there's going to be a real hanging party.
Poor _qgiver_, but that %ra's gonna pay twice the price of that _gem_.
1006: All evidence definitely points to %pcn as the ___qgiver_ thief.
_qgiver_ is continuing the search for that %ra, almost obsessively.
1007: It turned out that %pcn was innocent of the ___qgiver_ robbery.
That %ra mercenary was proven innocent of the ___qgiver_ robbery.
1008: I still feel terrible about wrongly accusing you, %pcf.
1009: Thief! Thief! Get out or I'll call the guards!
1010: %qdt: _qgiver_, a =qgiver_ in __qgiver_ of ___qgiver_ suddenly accused me of burglary, that I stole %g3 _gem_. I am, naturally, innocent, but it would appear that I will have to prove it if I want to show my face in %reg again.
1011: Poor _qgiver_ lost %g3 _gem_. A witness saw a %ra, like you, at __qgiver_.
_qgiver_ is still trying to track down the %ra adventurer who stole that gem.
1012: _merchant_ is a hard-working, basically honest __merchanthome_ merchant.
Not one to overcharge customers, that _merchant_. At least not too much.
_merchant_, eh? You'll find %g2 over in _merchanthome_ this time of day.
If you listened to _priest_, _merchant_ is a blight on all of %reg.
_merchant_ gets along with most everyone, but %g doesn't like _thief_.
1013: _noble_ is of the royal house of __noblehome_. %oth, %g3 family has ruled forever.
_noble_ is a typical member of %g3 class -- decadent, ruthless, arrogant.
_noble_ spends %g3 time over in the _noblehome_ this time of day.
_thief_ isn't too fond of _noble_, but most everyone else is.
_noble_ has had a longstanding disdain for ==priest_ and _priest_ specifically
1014: _priest_ is a cleric of ==priest_, of course, and quite a zealous one too.
_priest_ has risen above the scandals that plagued %g3 early days in ==priest_.
_priest_ usually can be found in meditation at _priesthome_ right about now.
Most everyone in __priesthome_, except _noble_, greatly respect _priest_.
The only person _priest_ obviously dislikes is that =merchant_, _merchant_.
1015: _thief_, well, %g's a retired jewel thief. Or semi-retired, as I understand.
_thief_ used to be quite a jewel thief in __thiefhome_ once upon a time.
Someone told me that _thief_ lurks about _thiefhouse_ this time everyday.
_merchant_ doesn't believe that _thief_ has reformed %g3 life at all.
1016: _witness_ is the name of that =witness_ who saw the theft at __qgiver_.
_witness_ is just a =witness_. You can find %g2 over in __witness_.
1017: A ragged beggar boy suddenly thrusts a letter in your hands and disappears before you have a second to question him.
1018: My Dear, Dear %pcn,     Sorry for this inelegant but expediential means of communication. Our enemies have made quite a mess of your, well, shall we say, not-quite-but-almost snow white life. As much as we respect and admire thievery, as you did not commit these particular honors, we think it best that you expose the true architect to the eyes and nooses of the admiring public.     The person with whom it would be most efficacious for you to speak is _witness_, a =witness_ you may find lolling about _inn_. You will probably not find %g2 the friendliest of persons. After all, %g is the witness who saw you at __qgiver_'s, stealing the _gem_. Nevertheless, with a little effort, you might gain some information from the encounter.     Good luck, my dear. There is surely nothing more tiresome than being accused of an act of wanton, diabolic avarice for which you are uncharacteristically innocent.-- The Necromancers
1019: Dear %pcf,       We know all about being falsely accused of crimes, but we are seldom in a position to combat the accusations. In your case, we are at least aware of the name of one of your accusers -- _witness_. I do not know if %g is working for one of your enemies or ours, or is a completely innocent pawn, but %g was allegedly the witness to the burglary at __qgiver_.       Be careful speaking with _witness_ -- %g may have powerful friends. Your best bet may be in speaking with %g2 in public. I understand that %g frequents _inn_ in __inn_. The Agents
1020: %pcf,       Awright, this is gonna be a quick note, but your pals in the Thieves Guild want to help you out. Now we don't know who actually took that _gem_ from __qgiver_, but we know you didn't. Let's face it -- if you had taken that _gem_, you wouldn't be in near as much trouble. You're a smart kid, smart enough to get away with it. But someone is framing you.       The person who identified a %ra who looked like you stealing the _gem_ was a certain =witness_ by the name of _witness_. Couldn't tell you whether %g's telling the truth or not, whether %g saw someone who looked like you or not, but we figure you can make those inquiries yourself. You can find this _witness_ in a tavern called _inn_ right in __inn_. Just watch out for yourself. This ain't a game. The Thieves Guild
1021: Dear Friend,       I know you didn't do it. You didn't steal that _gem_ outta __qgiver_ any more than I did. Who do I suspect? Well, there's this =priest_ in __priesthome_ who would be just as happy stealing gems and framing people as I would be drinking a cool ale on a hot summertide day.      I don't have any evidence, but you might wanna check into %g2. The name of this cleric is _priest_. Good luck. A Friend
1022: %pcn,      You dont know me and I dont owe you any favors and even after this you dont owe me nothing, you unnderstand? I used to work for this =merchant_ by a name of _merchant_. Now %g was a crazy one, %g was. Allways trying to find a way to get rich. And always quick to blame someone else when %g got caught with %g3 hands in the cookie jar. That's how I got put away.     If I was you Id look to see if my old freind had something to do with the steeling at __qgiver_. A Friend
1023: Dear %pcn,      Please forgive this intrusion. I am quite certain that your mind is on other subjects than polite chitchat, so I will come right to the point. I do not believe that you were responsible for the burglary in __qgiver_, but unless you prove yourself innocent, you will be forevermore persecuted for it.     There is a =noble_ of my acquaintance who I believe knows more about the affair than most. It may be that %g even arranged or even commited the crime. I can say no more, except that %g3 name is _noble_ and %g lives in __noblehome_.     And one final thing: %g has very powerful friends. Do not face %g2 at a disadvantage. A Friend
1024: Dear %pcn,       Perhaps it would interest you to know that there is at least one person who doesn't think you did it. Or maybe I should say two people in __thiefhouse_ don't think you did it. Me and the one who did it -- a =thief_ who did do the burglary.      Now, the truth is that I don't have any proof, but _thief_, that's the =thief_, has done that kind of jewel-robbing before. %oth, %g even spent time in jail for it.      So, maybe _thief_ didn't do it. Maybe. But if %g didn't, I can tell you this -- %g knows more about who really did it than you do. So if you want to find out who did it and who's framing you, go find this _thief_ and ask %g2 some questions.A Friend
1025: It's you! You're the one who robbed __qgiver_! Guards! Guards!   _witness_ slips you a note as %g flees
It's the %ra who robbed __qgiver_! Somebody help me!   _witness_ slips you a note as %g flees
1026: %qdt: I received a letter from the Necromancers, telling me about the =witness_ who supposedly saw me in __qgiver_, stealing the _gem_. The person's name is _witness_ and %g frequents _inn_.
1027: %qdt: The Agents of the Underking sent me a letter, identifying the =witness_ who said %g saw a %ra like me stealing the _gem_ from __qgiver_. _witness_ may be an innocent pawn or an agent of one of my enemies. I will not know until I speak with %g2 at _inn_ here in __inn_.
1028: %qdt: The Thieves Guild sent me a letter, letting me know that they know that I'm innocent of the burglary. They also mentioned the name of the =witness_ who said %g saw me stealing that _gem_. _witness_ frequents a tavern called _inn_. I should pay my respects.
1029: %qdt: I received a letter from an anonymous friend, identifying a =priest_ named _priest_ as a possible agent behind the _gem_ burglary for which I've been framed.
1030: %qdt: Someone sent me a letter about a =merchant_ named _merchant_ who would be just the type to steal that _gem_ and set me up to take the punishment.
1031: %qdt: According to a letter I was sent anonymously, there is an aristocrat named _noble_ in __noblehome_ who may know quite a bit about what really happened at __qgiver_.
1032: %qdt: I was sent a letter from an anonymous source identifying someone named _thief_ as a notorious jewel-thief living right in __thiefhouse_. Even if %g didn't actually rob __qgiver_, a conference may reveal who did.
1034: %qdt: _witness_ apparently slipped me a note when I talked to %g2 and %g called for the guards. I have been asked to meet %g2 at a place called _withouse_.
1035: Thank %god you got my note. I'm sorry about calling the guard, but I couldn't be seen talking to you. Listen, I can't talk long, but I know now that you didn't do it. I told the truth when I said I saw a %ra like you stealing the _gem_ at __qgiver_, but then I saw something else. There's this =merchant_ named _merchant_ who, I guess, found out that you were in town and hired someone who looks a lot like you to steal the _gem_ and hide it away. If you want to clear your name, get the gem out of ___mondung_, where _merchant_ has it stashed, or see if you can find any other evidence in _thiefhouse_, where _merchant_ hangs out. Now, I gotta go. Good luck.
1036: Listen, you gotta believe me. I really saw a %ra like you take the _gem_, and I thought it was you. But that's before I saw _noble_'s cousin in __noblehome_. That kid looks almost exactly like you, and I happen to know that _noble_ sent %g3 cousin to ___mondung_ just recently. It'd be a great place to stash a _gem_. The only other good choice would be _thiefhouse_, where _noble_ stays at night. As soon as I saw that cousin, I knew you were innocent. But you're going to have to get the evidence yourself. I have to go now. Good luck, friend.
1037: I wasn't lying when I said I saw someone who looked like you steal that _gem_ from __qgiver_. Then I saw that %ra again at _priesthome_, talking to _priest_, one of the priests there. I overheard the two of them say something about ___mondung_, and I then followed that %ra down to _thiefhouse_. From there, the %ra went to ___mondung_. A few minutes later, you came into my tavern. No one will believe your and my word against _priest_. You're going to have to find some evidence, either at ___mondung_ or _thiefhouse_ to clear your name. Now, I must go. Good luck.
1038: I guess you got my note. I'm really sorry all this happened, %pcf, but I really did see someone who looked exactly like you steal the _gem_ from __qgiver_. The person who did it was a master of disguise -- a master thief named _thief_. Shortly after the burglary, I was walking past _thiefhouse_ when I heard a voice which I recognized as the thief's, saying something about a stash in ___mondung_. When I saw who was speaking, I recognized the renowned _thief_. These days %g is a respectable member of the community and it will take evidence to convict %g2. I can't help you there, but I imagine what you need is in _thiefhouse_ and ___mondung_. Good luck.
1039: You got my note, I see. Listen, %pcf, I know that you didn't burgle __qgiver_, but you have to understand that my life won't be worth a silver if they see us talking. I work for _merchant_, which may not mean anything to you, but believe you me, %g practically runs __merchanthome_. If you want to clear your name and implicate my boss, you're going to have to get some hard evidence. If I were you, I'd either leave the region, or look for something on %g2 at _thiefhouse_, %g3 house in town, or ___mondung_, %g3 secret treasure trove. Now, I gotta go. You never saw me, %pcf.
1040: Listen and listen carefully, %pcf. This is what happened. I witnessed the burglary at __qgiver_, but I knew that if I told the truth about who really did it, no one would believe me and I'd probably get hanged for treason. So, I told everyone a stranger did it. Specifically, you. The real burglar is someone beyond suspicion -- _noble_ of the royal house of %reg. You're going to need some evidence to prove it and I'm not going to stick my neck out anymore. The only other thing I can tell you is that, during the weekends, _noble_ spends %g3 time at ___mondung_ and at night, at _thiefhouse_. Hope you can find some evidence in one of those places. Good luck and I'm sorry.
1041: Hi, %pcf. I couldn't talk to you at the tavern -- it was too public. I really was a witness at the burglary at __qgiver_. In fact, I did it. But the one who paid me to do it and the one who said I should blame a stranger for it was _priest_, a priest of ==priest_. Obviously, no one's going to believe you if you just come out and say it. You're going to need evidence. I can tell you that I stashed the _gem_ in a place called ___mondung_, but just getting the gem back isn't going to convince anyone. Check out _thiefhouse_ -- _priest_ spends a lot of time there at night. Maybe you can find something on %g2 there. Now, I have to go. I'll deny all of this conversation, but right now, I'll wish you good luck.
1042: No, I know you didn't do it, %pcf. It was a =thief_ by the name of _thief_. Most people in __thiefhouse_ know %g used to be a thief, but they all think %g's retired to a life of public service. I can tell you %g hasn't. You see, %g picks a stranger in town to blame all %g3 burglaries on so %g remains above reproach. I'd love to see %g2 caught, but you're going to need some hard evidence. Most nights %g stays at a place called _thiefhouse_, so I'd look either there or %g3 old hideout, ___mondung_. Watch yourself, %pcf, and good luck.
1043: %qdt: _witness_ told me that _merchant_ was really responsible for the burglary, but I'll need hard evidence to convince anyone. I may need to go to both _thiefhouse_ and ___mondung_ to find all I need.
1044: %qdt: _witness_ told me that a noble, _noble_ actually engineered the burglary, but, as %g is so far above suspicion, I'll need to find some evidence. The two places suggested were _thiefhouse_, where _noble_ frequents at night, and ___mondung_.
1045: %qdt: _witness_ confessed that %g knew who commited the burglary and it isn't me. On the other hands, _priest_, the true engineer behind it, will be difficult to convict. The two places where I might find evidence, _witness_ says, are _thiefhouse_ and ___mondung_.
1046: %qdt: _thief_, a notorious but supposedly retired jewel thief was responsible for the burglary for which I've been framed, at least, according to _witness_. Further, %g says, _thief_ is now so well respected, I'll need hard evidence to convict %g2. I might be able to find this evidence in _thiefhouse_ or ___mondung_, or both places.
1047: You have found the _gem_ that was stolen from __qgiver_.
1048: _merchant_ __merchanthome_  Dear _merchant_,       I hope everything in __merchanthome_ is fine and that you and your family are in good health. The weather, I understand, is clement, so I must commend you on ordering it for my visit.      On to business. You mentioned in your last letter that you were interested in a discount for my services because the _gem_ is not of top quality and you have already found a convenient scapegoat for the crime. I agree to your terms, provided that you make certain that this %ra mercenary is the fool you suggest. If the worm turns, you know as well as I do, that it's every man for himself. And if that =priest_ _priest_ gets involved, %g can destroy the whole affair.      I will see you soon, my friend.-- %n
1049: _noble_ __noblehome_  My Darling _noble_,     What a crafty, wicked thing you are. Don't think for a minute that I didn't suspect you were behind poor _qgiver_'s misfortune. It was very sweet of you to get the _gem_ I wanted, but I somehow thought that you were going to pay for it.    I don't want you to think I'm unappreciative, my dearest darling, but if that _gem_ is taken out of ___mondung_ and anyone traces it to me, you won't even be able to count how many fingers'll be pointing at you. I'd watch out particularly for that nasty little _thief_. This is the sort of blackmail %g'd love.    Nevertheless, the _gem_ was a very sweet thought and I thank you.Love, %n
1050: _priest_ __priesthome_  Dear _priest_,       Ignore my last letter when I applauded you for your enormous contribution to ==priest_. That _gem_ that you said was a donation was stolen from _qgiver_. If it becomes known that the gem was stolen for our temple, our prestige in %reg would greatly suffer. _noble_ already hates us, and with %g3 influence on the royal family, ==priest_ will have much for which to answer.      We will discuss at our next meeting what appropriate castigation this situation merits. Do not think of challenging the temple. Yours Regretfully, %n ==priest_
1051: _thief_ __thiefhome_  My Dear _thief_,     So, you're back in business, are you? When I heard about the affair at __qgiver_, I had a pleasant rush of nostalgia. Shall I ever fully forget the good old days when the two of us were partners? Surely no more than I shall forget when you framed me for a jewelry job in precisely the same way you're framing that %ra mercenary. That was at _merchant_'s business, wasn't it?    Don't worry, this is not a blackmail note. I will not tell anyone a word ... unless, of course, they ask. Naturally, my memory may fade should you tell me where in ___mondung_ you hide that _gem_.    Please write back with your own reminiscences. %n
1052: This does seem to be some incriminating evidence. Now you must consider to whom you'll give this letter.
1053: _noble_ was behind that burglary? Well, well, well. Here's what you need to do. I'll talk to %g3 family -- they'll be eager to diffuse this situation as cleanly as possible. You get the _gem_ to _qgiver_ in __qgiver_, so %g's happy. What an amateur burglar that _noble_ is.
1054: So _thief_ was behind the burglary that nearly ruined my business, eh? And now %g's trying to frame you. Well, I'll speak to the authorities and this friend of %g3. All I need from you is that _gem_. Bring it to _qgiver_ in __qgiver_ and that'll not only clear you, but improve your reputation with %g2.
1055: Blessed %god, this is no forgery! The writer is correct. _merchant_ has reason to fear me. ==priest_ will see to it that _merchant_ is brought to the proper authorities, but we must see to it that you are not considered to be any kind of accomplice. If you get the _gem_ and bring it to _qgiver_, we can be assured of %g3 goodwill, which we need. Hurry to __qgiver_ with that _gem_, %pcf.
1056: You got this out of _priest_'s cell in _thiefhouse_? %oth, it's priceless! Quickly, now, %pcf, get that _gem_ to _qgiver_ and I'll make spread the word around that the true thief of __qgiver_ is a priest of ==priest_!
1057: You're the thief _witness_ told everyone about! Guards!
Guards! It's the %ra _witness_ identified as the thief!
I have nothing to say to a common jewel thief. _witness_ told me all about you. Guards! Guards!
1058: You mindless %ra! Why couldn't you be content with being a scapegoat? _guard4_!
Why couldn't you just get out of %reg and left everything along, %ra? %oth, you'll wish you had!
1059: %qdt: The true thief will be exposed and punished, but first I need to get the _gem_ back to _qgiver_ in __qgiver_.
1060: After all this time, there is nothing you can do easily to salvage your reputation in ___qgiver_. You would be best to give the place a wide berth for some time.
1091: %qdt: I met with _witness_ who told me that the one behind the stolen _gem_ is indeed _merchant_. %g spends %g3 nights at home, in _thiefhouse_, and has a stash at ___mondung_. I may get out of this mess yet.
1092: %qdt: I met with _witness_ who told me that the one behind the stolen _gem_ is indeed _noble_. %g spends %g3 nights at home, in _thiefhouse_, and has a stash at ___mondung_. I may get out of this mess yet.
1093: %qdt: I met with _witness_ who told me that the one behind the stolen _gem_ is indeed _priest_. %g spends %g3 nights at home, in _thiefhouse_, and has a stash at ___mondung_. I may get out of this mess yet.
1094: %qdt: I met with _witness_ who told me that the one behind the stolen _gem_ is indeed _thief_. %g spends %g3 nights at home, in _thiefhouse_, and has a stash at ___mondung_. I may get out of this mess yet.
1100: You notice _qgiver_ sneak out of the door.
